perturbation.changed_text: The Agent shall provide Monsanto no later than the date that is the earlier of (i) one (1) business day after the last day of each of the Agent's fiscal months and (ii) the first business day of each calendar month (which corresponds to the first work day of Monsanto's closing period) a full, detailed report by country of the Roundup SKU's being sold during the past month, including but not limited to Monsanto SKU identifier, quantity sold, quantity of samples provided free of charge, total sales value by SKU (in local currency). perturbation.explanation: Shortening the reporting deadline to one business day may create inconsistencies with standard accounting practices and federal regulations. Public companies often require several days to close their books accurately and prepare reports, which this alteration contradicts, potentially leading to rushed, inaccurate reporting.

perturbation.original_text: Within fifteen (15) days following the end of each Program Year, the Agent shall deliver to Monsanto a Commission Statement which shall contain the final determination of the Commission due at the expiry of the Program Year and shall set forth any eventual adjustments, to the amounts paid up to the Agent under Section 3.6(b) during the preceding Program Year.
perturbation.changed_text: Within thirty (30) days following the end of each Program Year, the Agent shall deliver to Monsanto a Commission Statement which shall contain the final determination of the Commission due at the expiry of the Program Year and shall set forth any eventual adjustments, to the amounts paid up to the Agent under Section 3.6(b) during the preceding Program Year.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a potential inconsistency if the 15-day period is essential for meeting mandatory financial reporting deadlines or tax compliance requirements in certain jurisdictions. Extending it to 30 days could lead to delays in reporting, creating non-compliance with reporting regulatory standards.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of state tax or securities laws that require certain financial reports to be submitted within a specific timeframe.

perturbation.original_text: The Agent agrees that for the duration of the Noncompetition Period, without the prior written consent of Monsanto, it will not, nor will it permit any of its Affiliates to (i) solicit for employment any person then employed who works primarily with Roundup Products or with other products with Lawn & Garden Uses ("Lawn & Garden Employee") by Monsanto or any of its Affiliates or (ii) knowingly employ any Lawn & Garden Employee of Monsanto or any of its Affiliates who voluntarily terminates such employment with Monsanto (or such Affiliate) after the Effective Date, until three months have passed following termination of such employment.
perturbation.changed_text: The Agent agrees that for the duration of the Noncompetition Period, without the prior written consent of Monsanto, it will not, nor will it permit any of its Affiliates to (i) solicit for employment any person then employed who works primarily with Roundup Products or with other products with Lawn & Garden Uses ("Lawn & Garden Employee") by Monsanto or any of its Affiliates or (ii) knowingly employ any Lawn & Garden Employee of Monsanto or any of its Affiliates who voluntarily terminates such employment with Monsanto (or such Affiliate) after the Effective Date, until one month has passed following termination of such employment.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the employment restriction to one month is an anti-competitive practice, which is a violation of labor laws. Forcing the person to wait up to three months before getting employed is an offense.
